algorithms.curves

Class NonQuadraticConjugateGradientSolver

  • java.lang.Object
    • algorithms.curves.AbstractCurveFitter
      • algorithms.curves.NonQuadraticConjugateGradientSolver
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    ICurveFitter

    public class NonQuadraticConjugateGradientSolver
extends AbstractCurveFitter
    Class to find the minimum difference between a GEV model function(k, sigma, mu) and normalized data with errors. To make a solution faster than the very robust but slow downhill simplex method, would like to use the partial derivatives of the GEV to make an iterative solution for chi-square minimization of a non-linear, non-quadratic GEV model's difference from the data. This solution uses a pre-conditioner matrix with ICU0 function to help determine the next stop and direction. Useful for implementing the code below was reading: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fletcher-Reeves#Nonlinear_conjugate_gradient and http://netlib.org/linalg/html_templates/node64.html#figdilu and browsing various books on optimization ============================================================================================= Minimize f(vars) The function f is called the objective function or cost function. The vector x is an n-vector of independent variables: vars = [var1, var2, …, varn]T is a member of set Real numbers. The variables var1, …, varn are often referred to as decision variables. The optimization problem above can be viewed as a decision problem that involves finding the best vector var of the decision variables over all possible vectors in Ω. By the best vector we mean the one that results in the-smallest value of the objective function. This vector is called the minimizer of f over Ω. It is possible that there may be many minimizers. In this case, finding any of the minimizers will suffice. Df is the first derivative of f(vars) and is [partial deriv f/partial deriv var1, partial deriv f/partial deriv var1, …] ∇f = the gradient of f. ∇f = (Df)T F(vars) is the 2nd derivative of f and is sometimes called the Hessian. | ∂2f/∂2var1 … ∂2f/∂varn∂var1 F(vars) = D2f(vars) = | … … … | ∂2f/∂var1∂varn … ∂2f/∂2varn Example: Let f(x1, x2) = 5(x1) + 8(x2) + (x1)(x2) − (x1)2 − 2(x2)2 Df(x) = (∇f(x))T = [∂f/∂x1, ∂f/∂x2] = [5 + x2 − 2x1, 8 + x1 − 4x2] | -2 1 | F(x) = D2f(x) = | 1 -4 | -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- f(k, sigma, mu) = the GEV function Df = [∂/∂k, ∂/∂sigma, ∂/∂mu] | ∂/∂k | ∇f = (Df)T = | ∂/∂sigma | | ∂/∂mu | | ∂2/∂k∂k ∂2/∂sigma∂k ∂2/∂mu∂k | F(k, sigma, mu) = D2f(k, sigma, mu) = | ∂2/∂k∂sigma ∂2/∂sigma∂sigma ∂2/∂mu∂sigma | | ∂2/∂k∂mu ∂2/∂sigma∂mu ∂2/∂mu∂mu | M = D2f(k, sigma, mu) | ∂2/∂k∂k ∂2/∂k∂sigma ∂2/∂k∂mu | | ∂/∂k | M^(-1) * ∇f = MT * ∇f = | ∂2/∂sigma∂k ∂2/∂sigma∂sigma ∂2/∂sigma∂mu | * | ∂/∂sigma | | ∂2/∂mu∂k ∂2/∂mu∂sigma ∂2/∂mu∂mu | | ∂/∂mu | | (∂2/∂k∂k * (∂/∂k) + (∂2/∂k∂sigma) * (∂/∂sigma) + (∂2/∂k∂mu) * (∂/∂mu) | = | (∂2/∂sigma∂k) * (∂/∂k) + (∂2/∂sigma∂sigma) * (∂/∂sigma) + (∂2/∂sigma∂mu)*(∂/∂mu) | | (∂2/∂mu∂k)*(∂/∂k) + (∂2/∂mu∂sigma)*(∂/∂sigma) + (∂2/∂mu∂mu)*(∂/∂mu) | Can use Incomplete Cholesky factorization with fill 0 on M(-1) to create the pre-conditioning matrix. http://netlib.org/linalg/html_templates/node64.html#figdilu Let S be the non-zero set ({i,j} : aij != 0 ) for i = 1, 2, … set dii = aii for i = 1, 2, … set dii = 1/dii for j = i + 1, i + 2, … if (i, j) in set S and (j, i) in set S then set djj = djj - aji * dii * aij set d(1,1) = (∂2/∂k∂k) set d(2,2) = (∂2/∂sigma∂sigma) set d(3,3) = (∂2/∂mu∂mu) i = 1: set d(1,1) = 1./d(1,1) = 1./(∂2/∂k∂k) | (1,1) (1,2) (1,3) | = | 1/(∂2/∂k∂k) d = | (2,1) (2,2) (2,3) | = | (∂2/∂sigma∂sigma) | (3,1) (3,2) (3,3) | = | (∂2/∂mu∂mu) | j=2: set d(2,2) = (∂2/∂sigma∂sigma) - (∂2/∂sigma∂k)*( 1/(∂2/∂k∂k, that is ∂2/∂k∂k) ) * (∂2/∂k∂sigma) j=3: set d(3,3) = (∂2/∂mu∂mu) - (∂2/∂mu∂k)*( 1/(∂2/∂k∂k, that is ∂2/∂k∂k) ) * (∂2/∂k∂mu) i = 2: set d(2,2) = 1./d(2,2) = ( 1./ ( (∂2/∂sigma∂sigma) - (∂2/∂sigma∂k)*( 1/(∂2/∂k∂k, that is ∂2/∂k∂k) ) * (∂2/∂k∂sigma) ) ) | (1,1) (1,2) (1,3) | = | 1/(∂2/∂k∂k, that is ∂2/∂k∂k) d = | (2,1) (2,2) (2,3) | = | latest d(2,2) | (3,1) (3,2) (3,3) | = | (∂2/∂mu∂mu) | j=3: set d(3,3) = d(3,3) - a(3,2) * d(2,2) * a(2,3) = ( (∂2/∂mu∂mu) - (∂2/∂mu∂k)*( 1/(∂2/∂k∂k, that is ∂2/∂k∂k) ) * (∂2/∂k∂mu) ) - ( (∂2/∂mu∂sigma) ( 1./ ( (∂2/∂sigma∂sigma) - (∂2/∂sigma∂k)*( 1/(∂2/∂k∂k, that is ∂2/∂k∂k) ) * (∂2/∂k∂sigma) ) ) ∂2/∂sigma∂mu ) i = 3: set d(3,3) = 1./d(3,3) = 1./( ( (∂2/∂mu∂mu) - (∂2/∂mu∂k)*( 1/(∂2/∂k∂k, that is ∂2/∂k∂k) ) * (∂2/∂k∂mu) ) - ( (∂2/∂mu∂sigma) ( 1./ ( (∂2/∂sigma∂sigma) - (∂2/∂sigma∂k)*( 1/(∂2/∂k∂k, that is ∂2/∂k∂k) ) * (∂2/∂k∂sigma) ) ) ∂2/∂sigma∂mu ) ) Then using the ICU0 matrix as preconditioner: | d(1,1) 0 0 | | ∂/∂k | (M_icuo)(-1) * ∇f = MT * ∇f = | 0 d(2,2) 0 | * | ∂/∂sigma | | 0 0 d(3,3) | | ∂/∂mu | | d(1,1) * (∂/∂k) | = | d(2,2) * (∂/∂sigma) | | d(3,3) * (∂/∂mu) | where d(1,1) is 1./(∂2/∂k∂k, that is ∂2/∂k∂k) d(2,2) is ( 1./ ( (∂2/∂sigma∂sigma) - (∂2/∂sigma∂k)*( 1/(∂2/∂k∂k, that is ∂2/∂k∂k) ) * (∂2/∂k∂sigma) ) ) d(3,3) is 1./( ( (∂2/∂mu∂mu) - (∂2/∂mu∂k)*( 1/(∂2/∂k∂k, that is ∂2/∂k∂k) ) * (∂2/∂k∂mu) ) - ( (∂2/∂mu∂sigma) ( 1./ ( (∂2/∂sigma∂sigma) - (∂2/∂sigma∂k)*( 1/(∂2/∂k∂k, that is ∂2/∂k∂k) ) * (∂2/∂k∂sigma) ) ) ∂2/∂sigma∂mu ) ) Note that below in the code, r is ∇f.
    Author:
    nichole

      • fitCurveKGreaterThanZero

        public GEVYFit fitCurveKGreaterThanZero(GEVChiSquareMinimization.WEIGHTS_DURING_CHISQSUM weightMethod)
                                 throws FailedToConvergeException,
                                        java.io.IOException
        fit the x and y data using default ranges for the parameters k, sigma, and mu. The generated curves use parameter step sizes determined from using the k, sigma, and mu derivatives separately and keeping the best result.

      • fitCurveParametersSeparately

        public GEVYFit fitCurveParametersSeparately(float kMin,
                                            float kMax,
                                            float sigmaMin,
                                            float sigmaMax,
                                            float muMin,
                                            float muMax)
                                     throws FailedToConvergeException
        find the best fitting GEV by solving for each parameter in set {k, sigma, mu} separately rather then minimizing the function for suggested changes by all derivatives at once. So far, this is resulting in the best fits, but is sensitive to the starting point and has not been tested over a wide range of data distributions. The range of values given to this method by TwoPointVoidStats are those found to be most useful for representing the range of normalized GEV curves that match the datasets given to it. k < 0 are not fit because the distributions are not physical for the expected datasets, though that can be changed if needed.
        Parameters:
        kMin - minimum range of value of k, the shape parameter
        kMax - maximum range of value of k, the shape parameter
        sigmaMin - minimum range of value of sigma, the scale parameter
        sigmaMax - maximum range of value of sigma, the scale parameter
        muMin - minimum range of value of mu, the location parameter
        muMax - maximum range of value of mu, the location parameter
        Returns:
        Throws:
        FailedToConvergeException

      • fitCurveParametersAllAtOnce

        public GEVYFit fitCurveParametersAllAtOnce(float kMin,
                                           float kMax,
                                           float sigmaMin,
                                           float sigmaMax,
                                           float muMin,
                                           float muMax)
                                    throws FailedToConvergeException
        fit the x, y data with a GEV whose parameters are within the given ranges for k, sigma, and mu. The method attempts to fit for changes in k, sigma, and mu all at once for each iteration.
        Parameters:
        kMin - minimum range of value of k, the shape parameter
        kMax - maximum range of value of k, the shape parameter
        sigmaMin - minimum range of value of sigma, the scale parameter
        sigmaMax - maximum range of value of sigma, the scale parameter
        muMin - minimum range of value of mu, the location parameter
        muMax - maximum range of value of mu, the location parameter
        Returns:
        Throws:
        FailedToConvergeException

      • fitCurveParameters

        public GEVYFit fitCurveParameters(float kMin,
                                  float kMax,
                                  float sigmaMin,
                                  float sigmaMax,
                                  float muMin,
                                  float muMax)
                           throws FailedToConvergeException
        find the best fitting GEV by solving for each parameter in set {k, sigma, mu} separately rather then minimizing the function for suggested changes by all derivatives at once. So far, this is resulting in the best fits, but is sensitive to the starting point and has not been tested over a wide range of data distributions. The range of values given to this method by TwoPointVoidStats are those found to be most useful for representing the range of normalized GEV curves that match the datasets given to it. k < 0 are not fit because the distributions are not physical for the expected datasets, though that can be changed if needed.
        Parameters:
        kMin - minimum range of value of k, the shape parameter
        kMax - maximum range of value of k, the shape parameter
        sigmaMin - minimum range of value of sigma, the scale parameter
        sigmaMax - maximum range of value of sigma, the scale parameter
        muMin - minimum range of value of mu, the location parameter
        muMax - maximum range of value of mu, the location parameter
        Returns:
        Throws:
        FailedToConvergeException
